page.title: 01Village Setting and History
page.content: The name Marden is a legacy of the Iron Age Celts, the Cymry, or Welsh tribes who inhabited some of the many hillforts prevalent in this region.The name Marden is derived from Mawarddin (Maurdin, Maurdyn, etc.), themselves corruptions of Mawr Ddinas, Welsh for a large fort. As the reputed headquarters of Offa King of Mercia, Sutton Walls, is in the Parish of Marden it might seem connected with this. Etymologically, however, it appears to owe its origins to Dinmore Hill, as Dinmore is another variation on the theme of Dinas and Mawr. The roots of the village of Marden go a fair way down into the soils of time. Soil is really the keyword for this area as it contains some of the richest farmland in the country. Marden is surrounded by little hamlets, all one-time farming centres.
